abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Social Protection
            Project in Kosovo were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: i) The project design teams have
            to carefully assess the specific country situation, actual
            capacity at central as well as local government
            institutions, and have realistic expectations. This is
            especially important where the policy formulation and
            sectoral governance are weak. It is quite a challenge to
            prioritize the needs of a post conflict country, with
            completely devastated and abandoned social programs.
            However, defining clear priorities and, if needed, working
            out possible alternatives, is crucial for achieving the
            project expected outcomes; (ii) The project teams need to be
            flexible and consider developing possible alternative
            strategies in the course of project implementation, in order
            to ensure achieving all project objectives; (iii) Continuous
            government ownership and capacity building is fundamental
            for a successful project implementation and the
            sustainability of reform activities beyond project life.
            Although the daily management work for SP project was
            carried out by the Project Coordination Unit (PCU) members,
            the main responsibility for the implementation of each
            project component laid with the Department of Social
            Welfare, under the Ministry of Labor and Social Welfare.
            This Department, in close collaboration with all related
            institutions, is making laudable efforts to carry on the
            reform activities supported under the project.
